page.title: 13BLAKENEY RED PEARS
page.content: Blakeney Red pears are small, hard and dry tasting. They are used for making cider and wine. To make perry the pears have to be cleaned but to make cider with apples and Blakeney Reds it does not matter. Local people stew the pears in lemonade. The pips have to be black otherwise it tastes sour. The fruit has to be pulped and put into the press. Then the juice is pumped into the barrels. It starts to froth and after seven to eight weeks it turns itself over then it's nearly ready to drink. Local people believe that the trees grow better on the hillside, and produce better fruit. Most of the trees are very old. New ones are grown by grafting, and don't fruit for 15 to 20 years. The Awre Parish Council is planting some new trees beside the A48 at Nibley because they are in danger of dying out.
